questions.question: What is the time complexity of binary search?
questions.hint: Each step halves the remaining search space. How does that growth pattern relate to logarithms?

questions.question: In Swift, what is the output? let x: Int? = nil; print(x ?? 5)
questions.hint: The ?? operator provides a default value when the optional is nil. What gets printed when x has no value?

questions.question: What is ARP used for?
answers: Map IP addresses to MAC addresses
questions.hint: Address Resolution Protocol - it 'resolves' which type of address to which other type?

questions.question: What is the difference between TCP and UDP?
answers: TCP is reliable and ordered, UDP is faster but unreliable
questions.hint: One guarantees delivery and order (like registered mail), the other is faster but may lose packets.

questions.question: In Swift, what does 'weak' keyword prevent?
questions.hint: When two objects reference each other strongly, memory never gets freed. What cycle is this?

questions.question: What is the purpose of the TLB (Translation Lookaside Buffer)?
questions.hint: Virtual memory needs to translate addresses. The TLB caches these translations for speed.

questions.question: What is a race condition?
answers: When outcome depends on timing of uncontrolled events
questions.hint: Multiple threads 'race' to access shared data - the result depends on who gets there first.

questions.question: In Swift, what is the difference between map and flatMap on arrays?
questions.hint: One transforms elements normally; the other also 'flattens' the result if it's nested.

questions.question: What is a mutex?
answers: Ensures only one thread accesses a resource at a time
questions.hint: 'Mutual exclusion' - only one thread can hold it at a time. What does that prevent?

questions.question: What does DHCP do?
questions.hint: When your device joins a network, something 'dynamically' gives it an IP address.

questions.question: In Swift, what is the @escaping attribute used for?
answers: Closures that outlive the function that receives them
questions.hint: Sometimes a closure 'escapes' and runs after the function returns. What attribute marks this?

questions.question: What is page fault in virtual memory?
answers: When accessed page is not in RAM
questions.hint: The CPU requests a memory page that isn't currently loaded into physical RAM. What happens?

questions.question: What is the difference between stack and heap memory?
answers: Stack is LIFO and automatic, heap is dynamic
questions.hint: One is automatic and fast (LIFO structure), the other is for dynamic allocation.

questions.question: In Swift, what is a protocol?
answers: Blueprint of methods and properties a type must implement
questions.hint: Like an interface or contract - defines what methods/properties a conforming type must have.

questions.question: What is NAT (Network Address Translation)?
answers: Allows multiple devices to share one public IP
questions.hint: Your home has many devices but one public IP. Something 'translates' between internal and external addresses.

questions.question: What is thrashing in operating systems?
answers: Excessive paging that slows the system
questions.hint: When the system spends more time swapping pages than doing useful work - it's 'thrashing' around.

questions.question: In Swift, what does 'defer' do?
answers: Executes code when leaving current scope
questions.hint: This block runs just before exiting the current scope - 'deferred' until the end.

questions.question: What is the OSI model's Layer 4?
questions.hint: Layer 4 handles end-to-end communication and 'transports' data reliably.

questions.question: What is context switching?
questions.hint: When the OS switches from one process to another, it must save and restore the 'context' (state).

questions.question: In Swift, what is the purpose of DispatchQueue?
questions.hint: Grand Central Dispatch uses queues to 'dispatch' work to different threads.

questions.question: What is a semaphore?
answers: Controls access to shared resources using a counter
questions.hint: Like a traffic signal with a counter - limits how many can access a resource at once.

questions.question: What is ICMP used for?
questions.hint: When you 'ping' a server to check if it's reachable, what protocol sends those messages?

questions.question: In Swift, what is a computed property?
answers: Property that calculates its value on access
questions.hint: Instead of storing a value, this property 'computes' or calculates it each time you read it.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of quicksort on average?
questions.hint: Quicksort divides the array and sorts both halves. Average case is the same as merge sort.

questions.question: What is a system call?
answers: Request from program to kernel for service
questions.hint: When a program needs kernel services (file I/O, network), it makes a 'call' to the 'system'.

questions.question: In Swift, what is ARC?
answers: Automatic Reference Counting for memory management
questions.hint: Swift 'automatically' tracks 'reference' 'counts' to know when to free memory.

questions.question: What is a VLAN?
answers: Virtual LAN that segments network logically
questions.hint: A 'virtual' way to segment a physical network into separate logical networks.

questions.question: What is the difference between preemptive and cooperative multitasking?
answers: Preemptive: OS controls; Cooperative: processes yield
questions.hint: In one, the OS forcefully interrupts; in the other, processes must 'cooperate' and yield voluntarily.

questions.question: In Swift, what is 'inout' parameter?
answers: Parameter that can be modified and changes persist
questions.hint: Changes made inside the function persist 'out' - the value goes 'in' and comes back 'out' modified.

questions.question: What is a hash table's average lookup time complexity?
questions.hint: Hash functions provide direct access - on average, you jump straight to the item. Constant time.

questions.question: What is the purpose of HTTPS's TLS/SSL?
answers: Encrypt data between client and server
questions.hint: The 'S' in HTTPS stands for 'secure' - what layer provides that encryption?

questions.question: What is inode in Unix filesystems?
questions.hint: Every file has an 'index node' storing its metadata - permissions, size, block locations.

questions.question: In Swift, what is the difference between 'as?' and 'as!'?
answers: as? returns optional, as! force unwraps
questions.hint: One safely returns nil if cast fails (with ?), the other crashes if it fails (with !).

questions.question: What is a buffer overflow?
questions.hint: When data written to a buffer exceeds its boundaries, it 'overflows' into adjacent memory.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a load balancer?
questions.hint: Multiple servers share the 'load' of incoming requests - something 'balances' them.

questions.question: In Swift, what is a lazy property?
answers: Property initialized only when first accessed
questions.hint: The property is 'lazy' - it doesn't initialize until you actually need it.

questions.question: What is the difference between HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2?
answers: HTTP/2 uses multiplexing and binary framing
questions.hint: HTTP/2 can send multiple requests over one connection and uses binary instead of text.

questions.question: What is a memory leak?
answers: Memory that's allocated but never freed
questions.hint: Memory gets allocated but never released - it 'leaks' away from available memory.

questions.question: In Swift, what is @MainActor?
answers: Ensures code runs on main thread
questions.hint: UI updates must happen on the main thread. This attribute ensures code runs there.

questions.question: What is the CAP theorem?
answers: Distributed systems can't guarantee all of: Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance
questions.hint: In distributed systems, you can only fully guarantee 2 of 3 properties: C, A, and P.

questions.question: What is the hexadecimal value of decimal 255?
questions.hint: 255 is the maximum value for 8 bits. In hex, each digit represents 4 bits (0-15 = 0-F).

questions.question: What is the decimal value of hexadecimal 0x2A?
questions.hint: Convert each hex digit: 2 x 16 + A (which is 10). What do you get?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of inserting at the beginning of a linked list?
questions.hint: You just update the head pointer and the new node's next. No traversal needed.

questions.question: What does the hexadecimal color #00FF00 represent?
questions.hint: RGB format: RR GG BB. Only the middle pair (green) has value FF.

questions.question: What is the worst-case time complexity of quicksort?
questions.hint: When the pivot is always the smallest or largest element, partitioning is unbalanced.

questions.question: Convert binary 11111111 to hexadecimal.
questions.hint: Split into two 4-bit groups: 1111 and 1111. Each 1111 equals what in hex?

questions.question: What is the space complexity of merge sort?
questions.hint: Merge sort needs extra space to store the merged subarrays. How much?

questions.question: What is 0xA + 0xB in hexadecimal?
questions.hint: A is 10, B is 11 in decimal. Add them, then convert back to hex.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of accessing an element by index in an array?
questions.hint: Arrays provide direct access via index calculation. No searching needed.

questions.question: What is the hexadecimal representation of decimal 16?
questions.hint: 16 in decimal equals 1 x 16 + 0. What's that in hex notation?

questions.question: What is the amortized time complexity of appending to a dynamic array?
questions.hint: While occasional resizing is O(n), spreading that cost over all operations averages out.

questions.question: What is 0xFF in binary?
questions.hint: F in hex is 15 in decimal, which is 1111 in binary. What's FF?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of heap insert?
questions.hint: After adding at the end, you bubble up through the tree levels. How many levels?

questions.question: Convert hexadecimal 0x64 to decimal.
questions.hint: 6 x 16 + 4 = ? This is a commonly used number in programming.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of finding the minimum in an unsorted array?
questions.hint: You must check every element to be sure you've found the smallest.

questions.question: What is the result of 0xF0 AND 0x0F (bitwise)?
questions.hint: AND requires both bits to be 1. Do the high nibble and low nibble overlap?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of building a heap from an array?
questions.hint: Using the bottom-up heapify approach is more efficient than inserting one by one.

questions.question: What is the result of 0xA5 XOR 0x5A?
questions.hint: XOR gives 1 when bits differ. Convert to binary and compare each bit.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of depth-first search on a graph?
questions.hint: You visit each vertex once and traverse each edge once.

questions.question: What is 0x100 in decimal?
questions.hint: 1 x 16^2 + 0 x 16 + 0. What is 16 squared?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of Dijkstra's algorithm using a binary heap?
questions.hint: Each vertex and edge is processed, and heap operations are logarithmic.

questions.question: What is the result of left-shifting 0x01 by 4 bits?
questions.hint: Left shift by 4 is the same as multiplying by 16. What's 1 x 16?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of finding the kth largest element using a min-heap of size k?
questions.hint: You process n elements, each potentially requiring a heap operation on a heap of size k.

questions.question: Convert decimal 127 to hexadecimal.
questions.hint: 127 = 7 x 16 + 15. What's 15 in hex?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of radix sort?
answers: $O(n \cdot k)$ where k is digit count
questions.hint: It processes each digit of each number. How many digits times how many numbers?

questions.question: What is the hexadecimal color code for pure blue?
questions.hint: RGB format: which component should be at max for blue?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of counting sort?
answers: $O(n + k)$ where k is the range
questions.hint: You count occurrences (n) and iterate through the range (k).

questions.question: What is 0xDEAD in decimal?
What is the best case time complexity of bubble sort?
questions.hint: With optimization, if no swaps occur in a pass, the array is sorted.

questions.question: What is the result of 0xFF OR 0x00?
questions.hint: OR gives 1 if either bit is 1. What happens when you OR anything with all 1s?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of finding all permutations of a string of length n?
questions.hint: How many different arrangements can you make with n unique items?

questions.question: What is 0x8000 right-shifted by 8 bits (logical shift)?
questions.hint: Logical right shift moves bits right and fills with zeros.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of matrix multiplication for two n x n matrices?
questions.hint: For each of n^2 elements, you compute a dot product of n elements.

questions.question: Convert hexadecimal 0xCAFE to binary.
questions.hint: Convert each hex digit to 4 bits: C=1100, A=1010, F=1111, E=1110.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the Floyd-Warshall algorithm?
questions.hint: Three nested loops, each iterating through all vertices.

questions.question: What is the two's complement of 0x01 in 8 bits?
questions.hint: Invert all bits and add 1. What's the inverse of 00000001, plus 1?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the Bellman-Ford algorithm?
questions.hint: It relaxes all edges V-1 times.

questions.question: What is 0xABCD masked with 0x00FF?
questions.hint: The mask 0x00FF keeps only the lower 8 bits.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of checking if a number is prime (naive approach)?
questions.hint: You only need to check divisors up to what value?

questions.question: What is the hexadecimal representation of ASCII 'A'?
questions.hint: ASCII 'A' is 65 in decimal. Convert to hex.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the Euclidean algorithm for GCD?
questions.hint: Each step reduces the problem size by at least half.

questions.question: What is the result of NOT 0x55 in 8-bit binary (bitwise complement)?
questions.hint: 0x55 = 01010101. Flip each bit.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of finding the longest common subsequence using dynamic programming?
questions.hint: You fill a 2D table with dimensions based on the two string lengths.

questions.question: What does the hex value 0x0D represent in ASCII?
questions.hint: 0x0D is 13 in decimal. Which control character is that?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the knapsack problem using dynamic programming?
questions.hint: You fill a table with n items and W capacity.

questions.question: Convert binary 10101010 to hexadecimal.
questions.hint: Split into nibbles: 1010 1010. Each 1010 is what in hex?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of topological sort?
questions.hint: It's based on DFS, visiting each vertex and edge once.

questions.question: What is 0x7FFF + 0x0001 in 16-bit signed arithmetic?
questions.hint: 0x7FFF is the maximum positive signed 16-bit number. What happens when you add 1?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of finding articulation points in a graph?
questions.hint: Tarjan's algorithm uses a modified DFS, visiting each vertex and edge once.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of the hex float 0x1.0p3?
questions.hint: p3 means multiply by 2^3. What is 1.0 x 8?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of Kruskal's algorithm using union-find?
questions.hint: Sorting edges dominates. What's the complexity of sorting E edges?

questions.question: What is 0xFFFFFFFF in signed 32-bit representation?
questions.hint: All bits set in two's complement represents what negative number?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of Prim's algorithm using a Fibonacci heap?
questions.hint: Fibonacci heaps have O(1) amortized decrease-key operations.

questions.question: What is the result of 0x12 << 4 | 0x34?
questions.hint: Shift 0x12 left by 4 bits (multiply by 16), then OR with 0x34.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of A* search in the worst case?
answers: $O(b^d)$ where b is branching factor, d is depth
questions.hint: Without a good heuristic, A* degrades to exploring exponentially many nodes.

questions.question: What is the hex representation of the IPv4 address 192.168.1.1?
questions.hint: Convert each octet: 192=C0, 168=A8, 1=01, 1=01.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of finding strongly connected components?
questions.hint: Kosaraju's or Tarjan's algorithm uses DFS twice, each O(V + E).

questions.question: What is 0x80000000 in signed 32-bit representation?
questions.hint: The most significant bit set in two's complement is the minimum negative value.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the Sieve of Eratosthenes?
questions.hint: The sum of 1/p for primes up to n is O(log log n).

questions.question: What is the result of 0xF0F0 XOR 0x0F0F?
questions.hint: XOR of alternating patterns where bits never overlap in the same position.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the FFT (Fast Fourier Transform)?
questions.hint: FFT uses divide-and-conquer, splitting into halves log n times.

questions.question: What is 0xBEEF in decimal?
What is the time complexity of segment tree construction?
questions.hint: You process each element once while building the tree bottom-up.

questions.question: What is the hex color code for white?
questions.hint: White is maximum values for all RGB components.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of segment tree range query?
questions.hint: You traverse down the tree, going at most to the tree height.

questions.question: What is the population count (number of 1 bits) of 0x5555?
questions.hint: 0x5555 = 0101010101010101 in binary. Count the 1s.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the union operation in union-find with path compression and union by rank?
questions.hint: With both optimizations, the amortized time is nearly constant.

questions.question: What is the byte order for 0x12345678 in little-endian?
questions.hint: Little-endian stores the least significant byte first.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of Fenwick tree (Binary Indexed Tree) update?
questions.hint: Updates propagate through the tree structure logarithmically.

questions.question: What is 0x1 << 31 in a 32-bit unsigned integer?
questions.hint: Left shift moves the 1 bit to position 31 (the most significant bit).

questions.question: What is the time complexity of finding the median using the median-of-medians algorithm?
questions.hint: This deterministic selection algorithm guarantees linear time.

questions.question: What is the result of 0xAAAA & (0xAAAA - 1)?
questions.hint: The expression n & (n-1) clears the lowest set bit.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of Strassen's matrix multiplication?
questions.hint: Strassen reduces 8 multiplications to 7, changing the exponent.

questions.question: What is the hex value of the subnet mask 255.255.255.0?
questions.hint: Convert each octet: 255=FF, 255=FF, 255=FF, 0=00.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of binary exponentiation?
questions.hint: You square the base and halve the exponent each step.

questions.question: What is the lowest set bit of 0x48?
questions.hint: 0x48 = 01001000 in binary. Which is the rightmost 1?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the naive string matching algorithm?
questions.hint: For each of n positions, you may compare up to m characters.

questions.question: What is 0x7F interpreted as a signed 8-bit integer?
questions.hint: 0x7F = 01111111. The MSB is 0, so it's positive.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the KMP string matching algorithm?
questions.hint: KMP uses a failure function to avoid redundant comparisons.

questions.question: What is 0x80 interpreted as a signed 8-bit integer?
questions.hint: 0x80 = 10000000. The MSB is 1, so it's negative in signed form.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the Rabin-Karp string matching algorithm (average case)?
questions.hint: Rolling hash allows O(1) hash updates, making average case linear.

questions.question: How many bits are needed to represent 0xFFFF?
questions.hint: Each hex digit represents 4 bits. How many hex digits?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of suffix array construction using the DC3 algorithm?
questions.hint: DC3 (Skew algorithm) achieves linear time construction.

questions.question: What is the result of 0b11001100 >> 2 (logical shift)?
questions.hint: Logical right shift by 2 moves bits right and fills with zeros.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of LCP array construction from a suffix array?
questions.hint: Kasai's algorithm computes LCP in linear time.

questions.question: What is the hex representation of the Unicode code point for 'A' (U+0041)?
questions.hint: The Unicode code point notation U+0041 directly gives you the hex value.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of Aho-Corasick multiple pattern matching?
answers: $O(n + m + z)$ where z is output matches
questions.hint: After building the automaton, text traversal is linear plus output.

questions.question: What is 0xC0 in decimal?
questions.hint: C = 12 in hex. Calculate 12 x 16 + 0.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of computing the edit distance (Levenshtein distance)?
questions.hint: Dynamic programming fills a 2D table of size n x m.

questions.question: What is the result of rotating 0xABCD left by 8 bits in a 16-bit register?
questions.hint: Left rotation moves bits left, wrapping the overflow to the right.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of finding the convex hull using Graham scan?
questions.hint: Sorting points by angle dominates the complexity.

questions.question: What is 0x3F800000 as an IEEE 754 single-precision float?
questions.hint: This is a well-known constant in IEEE 754. Exponent is 127, mantissa is 1.0.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of Manacher's algorithm for longest palindromic substring?
questions.hint: Manacher's clever reuse of previously computed palindromes gives linear time.

questions.question: What is the two's complement of -5 in 8-bit binary?
What is the time complexity of treap operations (average case)?
questions.hint: Random priorities give expected balanced tree height.

questions.question: What is 0x0A in ASCII?
questions.hint: 0x0A is 10 in decimal. Which control character is ASCII 10?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of skip list operations (expected)?
questions.hint: Multiple levels of linked lists provide probabilistic balancing.

questions.question: What is the maximum unsigned value representable in 8 bits?
questions.hint: All 8 bits set to 1: 11111111. What's that in decimal?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of AVL tree rebalancing after insertion?
questions.hint: You may need to rotate at multiple levels going up to the root.

questions.question: What is 0x20 in ASCII?
questions.hint: 0x20 is 32 in decimal. ASCII 32 is a very common character.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of red-black tree insertion?
questions.hint: BST insertion plus potential rotations, all bounded by tree height.

questions.question: What is the result of 127 + 1 in signed 8-bit arithmetic?
questions.hint: 127 is the max positive signed 8-bit value. Adding 1 causes overflow.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of B-tree search?
questions.hint: The branching factor B affects the logarithm base.

questions.question: What is 0x30 in ASCII?
questions.hint: 0x30 is 48 in decimal. ASCII 48 starts the digit characters.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of trie insertion for a string of length m?
questions.hint: You traverse/create one node per character in the string.

questions.question: What is the sign bit of 0xFFFFFFFF in 32-bit signed representation?
questions.hint: The most significant bit (bit 31) is the sign bit. Is it set?

questions.question: What is the time complexity of computing the power set of a set with n elements?
questions.hint: How many subsets does a set of n elements have?

questions.question: What is the hex representation of the number -1 in 32-bit two's complement?
questions.hint: In two's complement, -1 has all bits set to 1.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the traveling salesman problem using dynamic programming?
questions.hint: DP with bitmask states: 2^n subsets, n^2 transitions per subset.

questions.question: What is the hex value of the 'magic number' for PNG files?
questions.hint: PNG files start with specific bytes including 'PNG'. 0x89 P N G...
